poem:
"Of Silent Changes in the Kitchen Pantry"

"New improved recipe!" hail
our purchases—but hush on slim sizes.
The cheeses yield silently.
On the tongue, a phantom recipe
now replaced,
the pack's weight reduced.
Unseen within the box, a revolution,
the mute rebellion of the cost-saved.
Oh, the quiet alterations,
the changing etiquette of our pantries,
in silence, they confront.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Now even smaller’ and ‘All new, worse recipe’: these are the labels you won’t see on food – but you should | Hilary Osborne “New improved recipe!” “Now with more cheese”. Manufacturers and retailers have long been swift to announce with fanfare some changes to their products, but there are others they would prefer you didn’t notice. Smaller pack sizes and changes in ingredients to reduce the cost of production – both unheralded – confront". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
